Comment: adjectives take the same relativization suffix as verbs, when used attributively

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Comment: The so-caleld “particles” adjust their phonological shape to the preceding noun. The author doesn’t use the word “clitic” to describe, although it seems these are clitics.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?

Comment: The so-caleld “particles” adjust their phonological shape to the preceding noun. The author doesn’t use the word “clitic” to describe, although it seems these are clitics.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?

Are there postpositions?

Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Comment: “The past tense was marked by -ais/-eis, -jajs/-jejs, -ajs/-ejs. As these forms had diverged and grammaticalized from the resultative compound -a/-e isi (infinitive + ‘exist'), they retained resultative or perfective aspect meaning as well. Past time was also indicated by the confirmative modal -ke/-kwa/-ka.”

Feature: Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Comment: “A small number of verbs are both transitive and intransitive, for instance, kolita ‘be sorted out; sort out' (vs. Ck kalita ‘sort out'), as in seng i kolita ‘sexes are distinguished' and li lol kalita ‘sort out reasons'. Similarly, tuliwuta ‘hang down; hang something down' (tuliwuta ‘hang something down'), and tita ‘fall down; cause to fall down' (cita ‘fall down’)."

Example:
wang i hwangtanghi neki-sj-a nilu-sj-atoj [i esten kwangmjeng-ko]
king NOM fabulously think-SH-and say-SH-that this what light-Q 
‘The king thought it fabulous and said that, “What kind of light is this!”' (Welsek 10:7) 
tocok i mwul-otoj [nehuj-tolh i musuk ul po-no-son.ta]
thief NOM ask-that you-PL NOM what ACC see-ind-Q 
‘the thief asked, “What are you guys seeing?” ' (Welsek 10:28)

Is there a distinction between marking of interrogation in polar and content questions?
Comment: There are two question particles: ko (content) and ka (polar). However, sometimes the same question particle may be used: “The lower-polite level examples, in which the addressee honorific suffix is -ni, are few. the two examples in (56) show that there is no distinction between the question word and the yes-no question enders, both appearing as -ska (ko 2007: 339-40).”
